all_results.feedback_quote: to better screen prospective applicants, I refer everyone to this guide: https://github.com/castorini/onboarding/blob/master/ura.md In particular, If you'd like further engagement with me, please complete the 'Foundations of Retrieval' onboarding path as part of the initial screening. This sequence of exercises provides a basic overview of the type of research that my group does. The ability to complete these exercises without assistance forms what I would consider the 'minimum bar' of the technical background that I expect of my students. Since these exercises involve a non-trivial amount of work, I want to clearly and accurately characterize 'the chances' that I'd accept you as a student. Many dozens of students express interest in joining my research group each year, of which I am only able to accept a couple. Successful completion of these exercises does not mean that I will accept you; it simply means that you've passed the first step of many. It will be a positive factor in my consideration of your application. My hope is that, regardless, you will have learned something in completing these exercises. If you'd like to start this journey, get started on the assignment. Drop me an email once you have completed the onboarding - by 'completed' I mean that your pull request has been merged into the main trunk of both the Anserini and Pyserini repos. In your email, send me links to your commit on GitHub so I can associate you with your GitHub user id.
all_results.feedback_summary: Professor provides explicit guidance on outreach approach: use the onboarding guide, complete the Foundations of Retrieval path, ensure PRs merged to Anserini/Pyserini, and email with GitHub links. This is concrete outreach strategy and timing rather than a generic rejection.

all_results.feedback_quote: "I always insist on a meeting over Zoom, Teams, or some other platform where we can have a face-to-face conversation. Often, a great amount of information for both parties can be learned from such a meeting. I realize that meeting over Zoom etc can sometimes be challening, so feel free to suggest an alternative video platform that you think may be viable. If so, at that point, you could email our grad director and ask whether the committee would consider an application from someone who already has a doctorate in another field."

all_results.feedback_quote: Although not all professors have time to read every email they get, your chances are much better if you find out more about their research by reading a few of their papers before writing to them, so you can explain how your interests connect to their research. The easiest place to find their publications is on https://scholar.google.com. I would definitely recommend using AI tools, e.g., NotebookLM, to try to quickly understand recent papers for potential supervisors.
all_results.feedback_summary: The professor provides explicit outreach strategy guidance: research the professor's work before emailing and tailor the message to connect with their research; use Google Scholar to locate publications; and leverage AI tools to quickly understand recent papers for potential supervisors.

all_results.feedback_quote: I would strongly encourage you to stop using generative AI to write initial contact letters to prospective supervisors. It is important to take the time to read their work carefully and to articulate, in your own words, how your interests genuinely connect to theirs. In your message below, for example, you cite an “article” that is in fact a conference abstract with very little content rather than a research paper, which suggests that you didn't actually engage with the literature.
all_results.feedback_summary: Discourages using AI-generated outreach and urges personal, literature-based, tailored emails. Highlights that mislabeling a conference abstract as a paper indicates a lack of engagement with the literature and advises crafting outreach in one’s own words to better connect with the professor’s work.

with_feedback.feedback_quote: to better screen prospective applicants, I refer everyone to this guide: https://github.com/castorini/onboarding/blob/master/ura.md In particular, If you'd like further engagement with me, please complete the 'Foundations of Retrieval' onboarding path as part of the initial screening. This sequence of exercises provides a basic overview of the type of research that my group does. The ability to complete these exercises without assistance forms what I would consider the 'minimum bar' of the technical background that I expect of my students. Since these exercises involve a non-trivial amount of work, I want to clearly and accurately characterize 'the chances' that I'd accept you as a student. Many dozens of students express interest in joining my research group each year, of which I am only able to accept a couple. Successful completion of these exercises does not mean that I will accept you; it simply means that you've passed the first step of many. It will be a positive factor in my consideration of your application. My hope is that, regardless, you will have learned something in completing these exercises. If you'd like to start this journey, get started on the assignment.
